title: In ‘Mr. Corman,’ Joseph Gordon-Levitt Looks Inward and Asks, ‘What If?’

content: Joseph Gordon-Levitt is the first to admit he’s had it pretty good. He has had a wildly successful acting career on stages and screens spanning over three decades. title: Track and Field Aimed for Inclusion. Instead It Sidelined Star Athletes.
description: Sebastian Coe, world track’s leader, has spent the past five years pushing his vision of a level playing field. Critics say he is violating athletes’ human rights.
content: For six years, Sebastian Coe, the president of track and field’s world governing body, has been fighting a battle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Pistons Select Cade Cunningham With No. 1 Pick in N.B.A. Draft
description: Cunningham, a 6-foot-8 guard out of Oklahoma State, becomes the latest part of Detroit’s pursuit of a resurgence.
content: The Detroit Pistons, a franchise that spent most of the last decade in the N.B.A. wilderness, will rest their hopes for a rescue on Cade Cunningham, the 19-year-old Oklahoma State standout guard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: A Night of Noshing Leads to Love on the Fast Track
description: Mosheh Oinounou and Alex Sall had their first date at the Jewish Food Society’s annual food event on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.
content: Mosheh David Oinounou and Alexandra Lauren Sall were shushed a few times as they whispered nonstop during a hefty lineup of talks on pastrami, knishes and other Jewish foods on their first date in October 2018. It took place at an annual event sponsored by the Jewish Food Society at the Angel Orensanz Center on Manhattan’s Lower East Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: China Targets Costly Tutoring Classes. Parents Want to Save Them.
description: Many families and experts say Beijing’s education overhaul will help the rich and make the system even more competitive for those who can barely afford it.
content: Zhang Hongchun worries that his 10-year-old daughter isn’t getting enough sleep. Between school, homework and after-school guitar, clarinet and calligraphy practice, most nights she doesn’t get to bed before 11. Some of her classmates keep going until midnight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: ‘The Jetpack Guy Is Back’: Los Angeles Sighting Draws an Inquiry, Again
description: Federal aviation officials said they, along with the F.B.I., were investigating the report of a person in a jetpack flying over Los Angeles.
content: A pilot flying a Boeing 747 on Wednesday night looked toward the right wing of the plane and reported a strange figure zooming over Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Vaccinated People May Spread the Virus, Though Rarely, C.D.C. Reports
description: The agency cited an outbreak in Provincetown, Mass., in which most of the infected were immunized. Unpublished C.D.C. documents paint an even more harrowing picture.
content: In yet another unexpected and unwelcome twist in the pandemic, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released on Friday a report strongly suggesting that fully immunized people with so-called breakthrough infections of the Delta variant can spread the virus to others just as readily as unvaccinated people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic, King of the Olympic Village, Loses Run at Golden Slam
description: An Olympic loss ended Djokovic’s bid for a Golden Slam — winning the four Grand Slam tournaments and the Olympic gold medal in singles in the same year.
content: TOKYO — Novak Djokovic’s dream of a Golden Slam ended in the early hours of another thick night at the Olympics, on one last searing winner off the racket of Germany’s Alexander Zverev.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Policing women’s bodies via dress code is nothing new in sports, writes our columnist.
description: In the end, the midsleeved, long-legged unitard didn’t make it to the gymnastics team final at the Olympics. The German women who wore it to combat the “sexualization” of their sport were eliminated during the qualifying rounds.

title: From ‘Call My Agent!’ to Hollywood Career
description: The French series was a pandemic hit in the United States. And now its star, Camille Cottin, is emerging to find herself in demand.
content: At some point during the pandemic, perhaps between the debut of “Ted Lasso” last August and “Bridgerton” in December, you may have happened upon Netflix’s French import “Call My Agent!” (“Dix Pour Cent” in French), a sweet yet absurd sendup of the global entertainment complex as seen through the lens of a Parisian talent agency where the agents are mostly good-hearted lovers of cinema at the beck and call of their highly demanding clients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Chuck E. Weiss, Musician Who, in Love, Inspired a Hit Song, Dies at 76
description: He and Tom Waits and Rickie Lee Jones were inseparable in the late ’70s, and when Mr. Weiss’s romantic life took a turn, Ms. Jones memorialized it in “Chuck E.’s in Love.”
content: Chuck E. Weiss, blues musician, club owner and outsize Los Angeles character who was immortalized in Rickie Lee Jones’s breakout hit song, “Chuck E.’s in Love,” died on July 20 at Cedars-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Infrastructure Deal Puts Cryptocurrencies in Washington’s Cross Hairs
description: A provision in the Senate legislation would give the I.R.S. more power to scrutinize a largely unregulated corner of finance.
content: WASHINGTON — In a hunt for funds to help pay for the Senate’s bipartisan infrastructure package, lawmakers have turned to the cryptocurrency industry as a potential source of tax revenue and are proposing tougher scrutiny of digital transactions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Delta variant is a ‘serious threat’ as contagious as chickenpox, the C.D.C. finds.
description: An internal agency document paints a grim picture of the fast-spreading coronavirus variant, saying it appears to cause serious illness and health officials must “acknowledge the war has changed.”
content: The Delta variant is much more contagious, more likely to break through protections afforded by the vaccines and may cause more severe disease than all other known versions of the virus, according to an internal presentation circulated within the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy La Gorce
title: After a Tragic Beginning, a ‘Happily Ever After’
description: Jaclyn Katz didn’t expect to find romance from a dating app — until she met Michael Sacks. She felt comfortable enough with him to share a childhood trauma.
content: Michael Sacks had only been seeing Jaclyn Katz for a few months in the spring of 2018 when she told him something tragic had happened in her past. He didn’t ask her to elaborate, and he didn’t search the internet for clues. “I thought, this is her story to tell when she’s ready,” Mr. Sacks said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe recovers from double-dip recession but lags the United States.
description: The eurozone economy grew 2 percent last quarter, as lockdowns eased and business activity stirred.
content: Europe’s economy exited a painful double-dip recession in the second quarter, rebounding faster than expected from the ravages of the pandemic as consumers spent pent-up savings and restaurants, factories and other businesses sprang to life after pandemic control restrictions eased.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judy Mandell
title: Finding Love Across the Hall
description: Chris Wiggins and Annie Jackson met nine years ago as neighbors and became fast friends, along with their roommates. They dated, broke up, then eventually moved in together.
content: Chris Wiggins moved to Manhattan with two friends in 2013 after they graduated from the University of Central Florida in Orlando. They split a one-bedroom apartment in Manhattan’s South Street Seaport neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate Chaos Is Avoidable. Here’s How.
description: The big changes that can still save us.
content: You might have read some dismal headlines this week: On Tuesday, enough ice melted in Greenland to cover Florida in two inches of water, fires are engulfing Northern California and parts of the Mediterranean, and Europe is still flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish Court Targets Chilean Bank Tied to Pinochet
description: Spurred by victims of Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s regime, the court  has reopened an investigation into whether Banco de Chile helped the former Chilean dictator launder money.
content: MADRID — Nearly 15 years after the death of the former Chilean dictator Gen. Augusto Pinochet, victims of his brutal regime are still trying to hold him and his associates accountable. And now the victims appear to be one step closer to justice — even if the courtroom is on the other side of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Richard Lamm, Governor and Early Abortion Rights Supporter, Dies at 85
description: He spearheaded the passage of a liberal abortion law in Colorado before Roe v. Wade, and he helped stop the 1976 Winter Olympics from being held in the state.
content: Richard D. Lamm, who as a Colorado state legislator led fights to pass the nation’s first abortion rights law in the years before Roe v. Wade and to block the 1976 Winter Olympics from being held in his state, and who went on to serve three terms as Colorado’s governor, died on Thursday in Denver. He was 85.

title: Those Virus Sequences That Were Suddenly Deleted? They’re Back

source.name: The New York Times

description: Here are all the answers to questions about swimming that you need ahead of Friday’s four gold medal races.
content: Twelve more medals will be draped around swimmers’ necks in the Friday morning session at the Tokyo Aquatics Center. The finals of the women’s 200-meter breaststroke, the men’s 200-meter backstroke, the women’s 100-meter freestyle and the men’s 200-meter individual medley also give viewers the chance to see a familiar image of athletes looking as if they are taking a bite out of their prize.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alexandra Kleeman Finds Reality All Too Surreal
description: Her latest novel, “Something New Under the Sun,” imagines a highly imaginable California so ravaged by drought and wildfires that only the rich can afford to survive.
content: It was 109 degrees Fahrenheit in the Mojave Desert on a Friday evening in July, down from 120. Alexandra Kleeman had seen people splash water on concrete to watch it evaporate, and a sparrow hunt a live cicada, killing and eating it right out of its shell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: A death in Kentucky is at least the fifth in the U.S. this month from flash flooding.
description: A woman was killed after heavy rain overnight led to flash flooding that washed away part of the trailer she was living in.
content: A woman in Kentucky was killed in flash flooding during heavy rain overnight that left about 10 people trapped in their homes and sent cars floating down streets, an official said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Elite Female Athletes Are Turning Away From Major Sponsors
description: Smaller brands are working with athletes in different ways, like giving them equity or roles in developing products, and are paying more attention to their personal stories.

title: Democrats scramble to save the federal eviction freeze, as frustration with Biden mounts.
description: Even if the House measure passes, it will almost certainly die in the Senate.

title: Georginio Wijnaldum and the Collective Toxic
description: No one can compare themselves to Simone Biles, but Wijnaldum’s exit from Liverpool carried many of the same themes.
content: This is not a comparison, because there is no comparison. Nobody, really, can understand what it is like to be Simone Biles. There have, of course, been athletes burdened with the same sort of level of superhuman expectation, their personhood erased in the transcendence to icon, turned into the face of a sport or an avatar for a generation or a standard-bearer for a nation, but they number barely a handful.

title: SPACs on Trial
description: Charges against the founder of Nikola cast a shadow over the blank-check boom.
content: Trevor Milton, the founder of Nikola, is one of the most high-profile figures at the center of the boom in SPAC deals. Yesterday he was hit with criminal and civil charges by the U.S. attorney’s office in Manhattan and the S.E.C. The prosecutors accuse Milton of misleading investors about the technology for the company’s battery- and hydrogen-powered vehicles. Nikola went public in June last year by merging with a blank-check firm, VectorIQ, founded by a former G.M. executive.

content: As the N.B.A. braces for the start of free agency negotiations on Monday, a pending blockbuster trade that would send Russell Westbrook to the Los Angeles Lakers is already in the running to be this summer’s most impactful transaction.

title: U.S. Authorities Seek Documents From Troubled Covid Vaccine Manufacturer
description: Emergent BioSolutions, which ruined 75 million vaccine doses at its Baltimore plant, disclosed records requests from Congress and federal and state law enforcement agencies.

author: By Jenée Desmond-Harris
title: What Should I Do With My White Privilege at Work?
description: My employer paid lip service to equality. Then it promoted me while displacing several highly qualified and experienced Black women. What should I do?
content: I am a white woman who was recently promoted to a high-level administrative position in my school district. At the same time, highly experienced and qualified Black women were displaced from their leadership positions. While the school district is requiring all employees to address issues of race and equity, our hiring practices do not reflect these values. I am challenged by my decision to continue to hold my leadership role and my position in the midst of these conflicting messages, actions and values. What can I do to address these inconsistencies and this discrimination?I’m sure you’re feeling guilty about how you may have unfairly benefited from your employer’s actions. But the district (including all the kids who go to school there) is better off with you in a leadership role than it would be with someone who didn’t care about discrimination. And your leaving, obviously, won’t make the district hire or promote more Black women. So I don’t want you to quit this job.

content: COLORADO SPRINGS — Three soldiers in camouflage were crowded around a table at a popular burrito place near Fort Carson on Friday, chewing over the announcement that the military might soon require all troops to get vaccinated for coronavirus. content: It was easily the wildest, most frenetic trade deadline in major league history. Ten players who were All-Stars in mid-July were traded by Friday afternoon.
